title: The Phantom Warning
text: I was drifting through town, lost in thought, when I stepped into the street without looking. A piercing shriek sliced through the airâ€”an old woman, her voice cracking like dead leaves, screamed for me to stop. I froze and turned just in time to see a bus thunder past, a blast of air clawing at my face. My heart pounded as I looked across to thank her, but the street was empty. No trace of her remained. Thatâ€™s when the chill set inâ€”she looked exactly like my grandmother, who ðŸ”µ buried seven years ago. I still remember the floral scarf she wore... the same one we buried her in.

title: The Pianist's Lament
text: We wandered into the skeleton of an abandoned theater, its air thick with forgotten breath. As we crept through its crumbling halls, a piano melody began to driftâ€”low, haunting, almost mournful. It drew us to the stage, where a dust-veiled piano sat, keys untouched, strings long dead. Then he appeared: a tall, gaunt figure in tattered evening wear, standing in the balcony like a relic of grief. He stared down at us, his eyes hollow with memory, before dissolving into nothingness. Later, I learned of the fireâ€”the pianist who perished mid-performance, still searching for his final ovation.

I couldnâ€™t sleep, so I glanced out my bedroom window at 2:17 a.m. The old playground across the street was soaked in moonlight. One swing was moving. Slow. Back and forth. No wind. No children. Just that rhythmic creak cutting through the silence.

I told myself it was nothingâ€”until it stopped suddenly.

The next morning, I found out a little girl had gone missing from that park years ago. Same swing. Same time.

What I canâ€™t explain is the muddy footprints I found beneath my window. Small ones. Leading toward my house.
title: The Empty Swing

text:
I was driving home on an empty highway when I noticed headlights behind me. They stayed at a constant distance for miles. No matter how fast or slow I drove.

At a red light, I checked my rearview mirror. The car was thereâ€”but the driverâ€™s seat was empty.

The light turned green. I didnâ€™t look back.

When I finally reached home and parked, the headlights were still behind me.

Then they shut off.

There was no car.
title: The passanger in the mirror

text:
I live alone. Or at least, I thought I did.

Every night before bed, I check the front door. Locked. Deadbolt secured. Chain fastened.

Last night, I heard it open. Slow. Careful.

I grabbed my phone and crept toward the hallway. The door was wide open, cold air spilling inside.

I checked the security camera footage the next morning.

At 3:03 a.m., the door unlocked.

From the inside.
title: The locked door
